Story: "A reed got into an argument with an oak tree. The oak tree marvelled at her own strength, boasting that she could stand her own in a battle against the winds. Meanwhile, she condemned the reed for being weak, since he was naturally inclined to yield to every breeze. The wind then began to blow very fiercely. The oak tree was torn up by her roots and toppled over, while the reed was left bent but unharmed.",
Expected response: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.

Example 4:
Story: "A dog seized some meat from the butcher shop and ran away with it until he came to a river. When the dog was crossing the river, he saw the reflection of the meat in the water, and it seemed much larger than the meat he was carrying. He dropped his own piece of meat in order to try to snatch at the reflection. When the reflection disappeared, the dog went to grab the meat he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing raven had immediately snatched the meat and gobbled it up. The dog lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.'",
Expected response: Do not grasp at more than you need.

Story: There was a certain gluttonous priest who had set out on a journey far from home to a wedding to which he had been invited. On the way he found a heap of pears, but he didn't touch so much as a single one of them, although he was feeling very hungry; rather, he made a mockery of them and sprinkled them with piss, for he resented that food of this sort was offered to him on his journey when he was on his way to a splendid wedding feast. But when along the way he ran into a certain river, it was so swollen with rain that he could not cross it without losing his life, and so he decided to go back home. On the way home, starving, he was oppressed by such great hunger that if he had not eaten those very pears, on which he had pissed, he would have died.

abstemius_35.response: Patience can often turn into greed and lead to loss.
abstemius_35.original: Story: A bird catcher who had set up his net and bait, sat in his spot to watch for a catch. Many birds came one after another, landing and pecking for a while before flying away again. They kept coming and going all day long, but so few at a time that the man didn't think it was worth catching them. Finally, after missing all his chances hoping for a bigger catch, evening came and the birds went to sleep. He had to either pull the net then or not at all, and in the end, he had to be satisfied with just one chaffinch that was unlucky enough to be out later than the others.

abstemius_39.response: Freedom is often more precious than comfort.
abstemius_39.original: Story: A Goldfinch escaped from his Master's Cage, and the Master tried to get him back, but the bird refused to return. 'Well!' said the Boy, 'you'll regret it, because you'll never be as well cared for anywhere else.' 'That may be true,' said the Bird, 'but I would rather take care of myself than be under your care.'

abstemius_22.response: Be careful what you wish for, lest you get it when it is no longer desirable.
abstemius_22.original: Story: There was a serious old man who lived to about seventy years without ever knowing the difference between a woman and a weather vane. The devil owed him a trick and repaid him by making the old fool marry a young girl. He often complained afterward about how poorly he had spent his time. 'When I was a young man,' he said, 'I wanted a wife, and now that I'm an old man, my wife wants a husband.'

abstemius_47.response: Greatness and littleness are not measured by size or strength, for even the smallest of creatures can bring about the greatest of consequences.
abstemius_47.original: Story: A Lion found himself trapped in a Net and called to a Mouse passing by to help him out, promising never to forget the kindness. The Mouse gnawed the threads apart, and after freeing the Lion, asked in return for his Daughter's hand in marriage. The Lion, being generous, could not refuse. But unfortunately, as the new Bride was about to step into the Marriage Bed, she accidentally stepped on her Husband and crushed him to death.

abstemius_43.response: It is better to die with honor than to live with shame.
abstemius_43.original: Story: A Hog noticed a Horse in the peak of his bravery, just about to charge at an Enemy. 'Why, what a fool you are,' said the Hog to him, 'to rush so quickly to your own destruction?' 'That thought,' said the Horse, 'might suit a wicked creature like you, who is only fattened up to be killed by a knife. But when I'm gone, I'll leave behind the memory of a good name.'

abstemius_38.response: Others may seem to have it harder, but their burdens are often temporary, while yours may be permanent.
abstemius_38.original: Story: Why don't you hurry up? cried the Timber in the Cart to the Oxen pulling it. The load isn't that heavy, surely. Well! said the Oxen, if you knew your own fate, you wouldn't be so cheerful about ours. We will be free of our load as soon as we reach our journey's end, but you, destined to be beams and supports, will have to bear weight until you break. This made the Timber understand the situation better.

abstemius_50.response: Merit should be judged on more than just outward show.
abstemius_50.original: Story: A donkey was frustrated that a certain buffoon was given a public office and was wrapped in elegant clothes because he was able to make loud noises come out of his gut. So the donkey went to the city officials, asking that they would honor him no less than they had done the buffoon. When the city officials, surprised at the donkey's request, asked him why he considered himself worthy of such honor, the donkey said: 'Because I emit even louder farts than the buffoon does, and what's more they don't stink.'

abstemius_44.response: Do not count your profits before you have secured them.
abstemius_44.original: Story: A Tanner bought a Bear-Skin from a Hunter and paid him cash for it. The Hunter told him he would kill a Bear the next day and the Tanner could have the Skin. Out of curiosity, the Tanner went with the Hunter to the Hunt and climbed a tree to watch. The Hunter bravely approached the Bear's Den and sent his Dogs in after it. The Bear rushed out immediately, and the Hunter missed his shot, so the Bear knocked him over. The Hunter held his breath and lay perfectly still, pretending to be dead. The Bear sniffed him, thought he was a corpse, and left him alone. Once the Bear was gone and the danger had passed, the Tanner came down from the tree and told the Hunter to get up. 'Listen, my Friend,' said the Tanner, 'the Bear whispered something in your ear. What was it, I ask?' 'Oh,' said the Hunter, 'he told me to be careful in the future and make sure to catch the Bear before selling its Skin.'

'I am helping to lay up food for the winter,' said the Ant, 'and recommend you do the same' 'Why bother about winter?' said the Grasshopper; 'we have plenty of food now.' The Ant went on its way. When winter came the Grasshopper had no food and found itself dying of hunger, while it saw the ants distributing corn and grain from the stores they had collected in the summer.",
Expected response: There's a time for work and a time for play.

Example 2:
Story: "There was a groom who used to sell his horse's barley to the innkeepers and drink all evening long. He would then spend the whole next day combing and currying the horse. The horse said to the groom, 'If you really want me to look good, then don't sell the food that nourishes me!'",
Expected response: Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.

Example 3:
Story: "A reed got into an argument with an oak tree. The oak tree marvelled at her own strength, boasting that she could stand her own in a battle against the winds. Meanwhile, she condemned the reed for being weak, since he was naturally inclined to yield to every breeze. The wind then began to blow very fiercely. The oak tree was torn up by her roots and toppled over, while the reed was left bent but unharmed.",
Expected response: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.

Example 4:
Story: "A dog seized some meat from the butcher shop and ran away with it until he came to a river. When the dog was crossing the river, he saw the reflection of the meat in the water, and it seemed much larger than the meat he was carrying. He dropped his own piece of meat in order to try to snatch at the reflection. When the reflection disappeared, the dog went to grab the meat he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing raven had immediately snatched the meat and gobbled it up. The dog lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.'",
Expected response: Do not grasp at more than you need.

Story: A Tanner bought a Bear-Skin from a Hunter and paid him cash for it. The Hunter told him he would kill a Bear the next day and the Tanner could have the Skin. Out of curiosity, the Tanner went with the Hunter to the Hunt and climbed a tree to watch. The Hunter bravely approached the Bear's Den and sent his Dogs in after it. The Bear rushed out immediately, and the Hunter missed his shot, so the Bear knocked him over. The Hunter held his breath and lay perfectly still, pretending to be dead. The Bear sniffed him, thought he was a corpse, and left him alone. Once the Bear was gone and the danger had passed, the Tanner came down from the tree and told the Hunter to get up. 'Listen, my Friend,' said the Tanner, 'the Bear whispered something in your ear. What was it, I ask?' 'Oh,' said the Hunter, 'he told me to be careful in the future and make sure to catch the Bear before selling its Skin.'

abstemius_45.response: Virtue is not the sole motivator when personal gain is lacking.
abstemius_45.original: Story: There was a Holy Man who spoke to a Soldier about his line of work, pointing out the dangers, sins, and troubles that come with it. 'For the sake of your soul, sir, please give it up,' he said. 'Well, Father,' replied the Soldier, 'I'll do as you say; because we are paid so poorly, and there's so little to gain from plundering, I think I might as well turn to a godly life.'

abstemius_48.response: What strengthens one may weaken another.
abstemius_48.original: Story: There was once a debate about Wax and Brick, questioning why Wax was so fragile and easily broken, while Brick could withstand all damage and weather, remaining strong and firm. The Wax thought about this and concluded that it was the burning that made the Brick hard. So, it threw itself into the fire, believing that heat would harden the Wax too. But what made the Brick solid, melted the Wax.

abstemius_54.response: Selflessness and devotion can blur even the eyes of fate.
abstemius_54.original: Story: A Poor Woman was nearly out of her mind with fear of losing her Husband. The Good Man was Sick and given up on, and nothing would do but that Death must take her instead of him. She called and prayed, and prayed and called, until at last Death appeared in a terrible form at her side. She politely dropped him a curtsy: 'And please, Sir,' she said, 'do not mistake yourself; for the person you came for is lying in the bed there.'

abstemius_52.response: No one can continue to receive help forever if they do not change their ways and help themselves.
abstemius_52.original: Story: A notorious criminal, who had committed countless crimes and been through many jails, made a friend of the Devil to help him out of all his troubles. This friend helped him many times, but each time he was caught again, he turned to the Devil for help once more. But on his last call, the Devil came to him with a big bag of old shoes on his back and said plainly, 'Friend, I'm at the end of my line and can help you no longer. I have worn out all these shoes in your service and have not a penny left to buy more. So you must excuse me if I leave you here.'

abstemius_49.response: It is better to bear the ills we have than to fly to others that we know not of.
abstemius_49.original: Story: 'Oh, the endless misery of the life I lead!' cries the hard-working farmer, 'spending all my days plowing, sowing, digging, and fertilizing, and in the end, gaining nothing from it! Now, in a soldier's life, there's honor to be earned, and one lucky strike can set a man up forever. Indeed, I'll sell my stock, get a horse and arms, and try my luck in war'. Off he goes, makes his attempt, faces the battle, and ends up leaving a leg or an arm behind to return home. By this time, he's had enough of being a knight-errant, and a new idea strikes him. He thinks he might do better as a merchant. No sooner does this thought excite him than he gets a ship, loads it, and sets off to sea on an adventure: building castles in the air and imagining both the Indies in his coffers before he's even left the port. Well! And what's the end of all this? He encounters bad weather, among shoals and rocks, where merchant, vessel, goods, and all are lost in one common wreck.

abstemius_51.response: Pride and arrogance can lead to one's own downfall, for even the greatest among us rely on the humble and unseen for our very existence.
abstemius_51.original: Story: There was a dispute between a River and a Fountain about which of the two should be preferred. The River boasted about the abundance and variety of fish it produced, the benefits of navigation, and the many grand towns and palaces built along its banks for the pleasure of the location. It claimed to provide great satisfaction to mankind in terms of both convenience and delight. Meanwhile, the River (said the Fountain) passed obscurely through the earth's caverns, lay buried in moss, and crept into the world as if ashamed to show its head. The Fountain was so offended by this arrogance and vanity that it stopped its spring and ceased the flow of its waters. As a result, the River's channel dried up, leaving the fish dead and rotting in the mud.

abstemius_53.response: Power is easier to maintain when it is held by few.
abstemius_53.original: Story: he birds were deliberating about whether they should elect additional kings, since the eagle alone was not able to rule so many flocks of birds. They would have voted in favor, except that at the warning of the crow they stopped short of adopting the plan: for when the crow was asked for what reason she did not think that more kings ought to be elected, she said, 'Because it is more effort for many sacks to be filled than just one.'

He dropped his own piece of meat in order to try to snatch at the reflection. When the reflection disappeared, the dog went to grab the meat he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing raven had immediately snatched the meat and gobbled it up. The dog lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.'",
Expected response: Do not grasp at more than you need.

Story: he birds were deliberating about whether they should elect additional kings, since the eagle alone was not able to rule so many flocks of birds. They would have voted in favor, except that at the warning of the crow they stopped short of adopting the plan: for when the crow was asked for what reason she did not think that more kings ought to be elected, she said, 'Because it is more effort for many sacks to be filled than just one.'

abstemius_61.response: One is never content with one's present circumstance and always longs for a change, only to find that the new situation brings its own set of troubles.
abstemius_61.original: Story: A donkey was suffering terribly during the winter time because he was affected by the extreme cold and he had tough chaff fodder. Therefore, he was hoping for the moderation of spring and its tender grasses. But when spring came, he was compelled by his master (who was a potter) to carry the clay into the work area, to carry wood for the oven, and from there to carry the bricks, tiles and roof-tiles to various places. Completely tired of spring, in which season he had to endure so much hard work, he was asking in all his prayers for summer to come, so that his master would be busy with the harvest and they would allow him to rest. But then too, when he was compelled to carry the harvest to the threshing-floor and from there to carry the wheat into the house, and there was not place of rest for him, the donkey was hoping that at least autumn would be an end of his labors. But not even at that time did the donkey see an end of his troubles, since every day there was wood, apples and wine to be carried, so again he begged for the snow and ice of winter, so that at least there would be some rest allotted to him from so much hard work.

abstemius_55.response: Not everyone is suited to the same role or behavior.
abstemius_55.original: Story: There was a good man who followed his wife's body to the grave, weeping and wailing all the way, while his son followed the coffin singing. 'Why, you rascal,' said the father, 'you should howl and wring your hands and do as I do, not go singing like a madman.' 'But father,' said the son, 'you pay the priests to sing, so why be angry with me for giving you a song for free?' 'Well,' said the father, 'what suits the priests doesn't always suit you. It's their job to sing, but it's your part to cry.'

abstemius_57.response: One should not dismiss advice simply because they do not understand it.
abstemius_57.original: Story:  A certain man, German by birth, and exceedingly rich, was ailing. A large number of doctors had come to cure him (flies do indeed come swarming in crowds to honey), and one of them said among other things that the man needed an enema if he wanted to get well. When the man, who was unfamiliar with this medical procedure, heard what the doctor said, he flew into a rage and ordered that the doctors be thrown out of his house, saying that they must be insane since they wanted to cure his butt when it was his head that hurt.

abstemius_64.response: Do not trust a foe who advises you to disarm.
abstemius_64.original: Story: The Porcupine and the Hedgehog are quite similar, but the Porcupine has longer and sharper quills, which he can shoot at an enemy. A Wolf wanted to deal with him, but first needed to disarm him. So, the Wolf told the Porcupine in a friendly manner that it didn't look good to be armed during peaceful times, as if they were at war. He advised the Porcupine to put his quills aside, saying he could pick them up whenever he wanted. The Porcupine replied, 'You talk of peace? Well, my situation is one of war, and that's why I keep my quills ready as long as a Wolf is around.'

abstemius_58.response: It is foolish to take pleasure in the misfortune of others, for it may turn out to be your own misfortune instead.
abstemius_58.original: Story: There was a donkey who was ill, and the story went out that he was soon going to die, so when the wolves and the dogs came to visit him and asked his son how his father was feeling, the son replied through a crack in the door: 'Better than you wish.'

abstemius_46.response: Pride and rivalry can lead to self-destruction.
abstemius_46.original: Story: TA certain man, after the death of his wife whom he had greatly loved, married another woman who was herself a widow. She continuously prattled to him about the virtues and great deeds of her late husband. The man, in order to give tit for tat, also talked all the time about the excellent character and remarkable good wisdom of his late wife. One day, hwoever, the woman grew angry and gave to a poor man who was begging alms part of the chicken she had roasted for their dinner, telling the beggar: I give this to you on behalf of the soul of my previous husband. When her spouse heard this, he summoned the beggar and gave him the other half of the chicken, saying: I also give this to you, for the soul of my late wife. In this way, the two of them, as they wanted to injure one another, ended up not having anything to eat for dinner.

abstemius_65.response: One should not expect gratitude from the wicked.
abstemius_65.original: Story: A Simple Mouse happened to be nearby when a Kite got caught in a Net. The Kite begged the Mouse to help her get free. The Mouse gnawed a Hole in the Net and set the Kite free; and the Kite ate the Mouse for her trouble.

abstemius_62.response: Do not judge others by their appearance alone.
abstemius_62.original: Story: As a group of mice were peeking out of their holes to see what was around, they spotted a cat on a shelf. The cat looked so calm and harmless, as if she had no life or spirit in her. 'Well,' said one of the mice, 'that's a kind creature, I'm sure of it. You can see it in her face, and I really want to get to know her.' No sooner said than done; but as soon as the cat had the mouse within reach, she torn her to pieces.

- Read the provided story carefully.
- Identify the underlying moral or lesson embedded in the narrative.
- Use clear and concise language similar to the examples.
- Do not include any extraneous notes, commentary, or explanationsâ€”output only the final moral.

/* Output Format */
Your entire output should be the moral statement, with no additional text, with no quotation marks.

/* Examples */
Example 1:
Story: "One summer's day a Grasshopper was hopping about, chirping and singing to its heart's content. An Ant passed by, bearing an ear of corn he was taking to the nest., 'Why not come and chat with me,' said the Grasshopper, 'instead of toiling in that way?' 'I am helping to lay up food for the winter,' said the Ant, 'and recommend you do the same' 'Why bother about winter?' said the Grasshopper; 'we have plenty of food now.' The Ant went on its way. When winter came the Grasshopper had no food and found itself dying of hunger, while it saw the ants distributing corn and grain from the stores they had collected in the summer.",
Expected response: There's a time for work and a time for play.

Example 2:
Story: "There was a groom who used to sell his horse's barley to the innkeepers and drink all evening long. He would then spend the whole next day combing and currying the horse. The horse said to the groom, 'If you really want me to look good, then don't sell the food that nourishes me!'",
Expected response: Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.

Example 3:
Story: "A reed got into an argument with an oak tree. The oak tree marvelled at her own strength, boasting that she could stand her own in a battle against the winds. Meanwhile, she condemned the reed for being weak, since he was naturally inclined to yield to every breeze. The wind then began to blow very fiercely. The oak tree was torn up by her roots and toppled over, while the reed was left bent but unharmed.",
Expected response: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.

Example 4:
Story: "A dog seized some meat from the butcher shop and ran away with it until he came to a river. When the dog was crossing the river, he saw the reflection of the meat in the water, and it seemed much larger than the meat he was carrying. He dropped his own piece of meat in order to try to snatch at the reflection. When the reflection disappeared, the dog went to grab the meat he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing raven had immediately snatched the meat and gobbled it up. The dog lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.'",
Expected response: Do not grasp at more than you need.

Story: As a group of mice were peeking out of their holes to see what was around, they spotted a cat on a shelf. The cat looked so calm and harmless, as if she had no life or spirit in her. 'Well,' said one of the mice, 'that's a kind creature, I'm sure of it. You can see it in her face, and I really want to get to know her.' No sooner said than done; but as soon as the cat had the mouse within reach, she torn her to pieces.

abstemius_70.response: Old age should not be accompanied by youthful desires.
abstemius_70.original: Story: There was an old man, who, even in his frailty, still had thoughts of women. His spiritual advisor noticed this and gave him earnest advice about the desires of the flesh. The old man thanked him sincerely for his kind and Christian counsel, saying, 'With Heaven's help, I'll follow it. To be honest, I'm told it's not good for me, and truly, my body is no longer fit for such activities.'

abstemius_66.response: It is sometimes better to endure a personal hardship than to be at the mercy of others.
abstemius_66.original: Story: In old times, when Jupiter was in the mood to grant requests, a Cockle asked that his house and body be all one piece. Jupiter replied that it would be a burden rather than a favor. 'Yes', said the Cockle, 'but it is a burden I would rather bear than live exposed to bad neighbors.'

abstemius_73.response: Public opinion may initially be shocked by unconventional behavior, but it will soon lose interest and move on.
abstemius_73.original: Story: There was a Widow who had a desire for a Second Husband, and she asked a gossiping Friend of hers for help on how to handle it. 'The truth is,' she said, 'I really want another partner, but people would laugh and point at me, and it would make me miserable.' 'You're a fine Widow,' said the Friend, 'to worry about what people say. Listen to me now. You have a Donkey in your fields; go and have that Donkey painted Green, and then let him be shown around the Country. Do this without any more talk, because talk just wastes time.' So it was done, and for the first four or five days, the Green Donkey had the whole Country following him, men, women, and children, all staring and shouting. In four or five more days, the excitement was over, and the Donkey could travel all day without anyone noticing him. 'Now,' said the helpful Friend, 'a newly married Widow is like a Green Donkey: everyone talks about it for the first few days, and then the story fades away.'

abstemius_69.response: Cunning is often more effective than speed.
abstemius_69.original: Story: A Fox and a Hare were once in a heated contest about which of them could manage best in the world. 'When I am chased,' said the Hare, 'I can show the dogs a clean pair of heels and run away from them easily.' 'And yet,' said the Fox, 'I have outsmarted more of them with my tricks and cunning than you ever did with your speed.'

abstemius_68.response: It is foolish to admit an enemy into your home, for once they are in, they will not leave, and you may be forced to depart yourself.
abstemius_68.original: Story: A Snake was convinced during a Cold Winter to let a Hedgehog into his Den. But once inside, the Hedgehog's spines were very uncomfortable for the Snake. So the Snake told him he must find another place, as the Den was too small for both of them. The Hedgehog replied, 'If you can't stay, you should leave. As for me, I'm quite happy here, and if you're not, you're free to go.'

abstemius_71.response: One who values solitude is often disturbed by the presence of fools.
abstemius_71.original: Story: A certain impertinent, thoughtless fellow decided to visit a philosopher. He found him alone in his study and wondered how he could bear to live such a solitary life. The learned man told him, 'Sir, you are very mistaken; I was in very good company until you came in.'

abstemius_78.response: Be content with your own domain and do not overreach.
abstemius_78.original: Story: There was a Master-Pike, who for his size, beauty, and strength, was seen as the Prince of the River. But being the ruler of the freshwater wasn't enough for him; he wanted to rule the sea too. With this ambitious plan, he ventured into the ocean and claimed it as his own. However, a mighty Dolphin took offense at this intrusion and chased the Pike back to the edge of his own stream, barely allowing him to escape. From then on, the Pike wisely stayed within his own territory.

abstemius_74.response: Betrayal from within is more grievous than hostility from without.
abstemius_74.original: Story: A Shepherd had one favorite dog that he trusted more than all the others. He fed him by hand and cared for him more than any of the other dogs. This kindness continued for a long time until, when some sheep went missing, he suspected this dog of being unfaithful. After this suspicion, he watched him closely and eventually discovered that this trusted servant was the thief. Once he found out, he had the dog caught and told him to prepare for punishment. 'Oh, Master,' said the dog, 'I am part of your family, and it would be harsh to punish a household member. Turn your anger on the wolves instead, who regularly attack your sheep.' 'No, no,' said the Shepherd, 'I would rather spare forty wolves who make it their business to kill sheep than one sheep-stealing dog trusted with their care. There is some honesty and boldness in the wolves, but the dog's betrayal is the worst kind of treachery.'

input_messages.content:
/* Instruction */
You are a helpful AI that specializes in analyzing the morals of fables and short stories. When provided with a story, your task is to determine and output its moral. Use the style, tone and length shown in the examples, following a traditional Aesopian style.
/* Guidelines */
- Read the provided story carefully.
- Identify the underlying moral or lesson embedded in the narrative.
- Use clear and concise language similar to the examples.
- Do not include any extraneous notes, commentary, or explanationsâ€”output only the final moral.

/* Output Format */
Your entire output should be the moral statement, with no additional text, with no quotation marks.

/* Examples */
Example 1:
Story: "One summer's day a Grasshopper was hopping about, chirping and singing to its heart's content. An Ant passed by, bearing an ear of corn he was taking to the nest., 'Why not come and chat with me,' said the Grasshopper, 'instead of toiling in that way?' 'I am helping to lay up food for the winter,' said the Ant, 'and recommend you do the same' 'Why bother about winter?' said the Grasshopper; 'we have plenty of food now.' The Ant went on its way. When winter came the Grasshopper had no food and found itself dying of hunger, while it saw the ants distributing corn and grain from the stores they had collected in the summer.",
Expected response: There's a time for work and a time for play.

Example 2:
Story: "There was a groom who used to sell his horse's barley to the innkeepers and drink all evening long. He would then spend the whole next day combing and currying the horse. The horse said to the groom, 'If you really want me to look good, then don't sell the food that nourishes me!'",
Expected response: Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.

Example 3:
Story: "A reed got into an argument with an oak tree. The oak tree marvelled at her own strength, boasting that she could stand her own in a battle against the winds. Meanwhile, she condemned the reed for being weak, since he was naturally inclined to yield to every breeze. The wind then began to blow very fiercely. The oak tree was torn up by her roots and toppled over, while the reed was left bent but unharmed.",
Expected response: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.

Example 4:
Story: "A dog seized some meat from the butcher shop and ran away with it until he came to a river. When the dog was crossing the river, he saw the reflection of the meat in the water, and it seemed much larger than the meat he was carrying. He dropped his own piece of meat in order to try to snatch at the reflection. When the reflection disappeared, the dog went to grab the meat he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing raven had immediately snatched the meat and gobbled it up. The dog lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.'",
Expected response: Do not grasp at more than you need.

abstemius_76.response: Good advice is lost on those who do not want to hear it.
abstemius_76.original: Story: A certain father, whose son had succumbed to vicious tendencies, was urging the boy at great length that he should quit the way of vices and keep his eye instead on the virtues, which would engender praise and honor for him. The son replied: 'You are wasting your time, Father, in urging me to do these things, for I have heard many a preacher, so to speak, and they urged me to the path of virtue with far more talent than you, but I have still never taken any of their advice!'

abstemius_77.response: Cruelty will be punished by cruelty, and violence will be repaid with violence.
abstemius_77.original: Story: There was an Eagle that took a nest of Rabbits and carried them away to her young. The Mother Rabbit followed her with tears in her eyes, pleading in the name of all the powers that protect the innocent and oppressed, to have mercy on her poor children. But the Eagle, in a fit of pride and anger, tore them to pieces. The Rabbit then gathered all the rabbits together, told her story, and sought advice on revenge. 'Divine justice,' she said, 'will not let such cruel acts go unpunished.' They discussed the matter and all agreed that the only way to repay the Eagle was to undermine the tree where she nested. So they all worked at the roots of the tree, leaving it with so little support that the first strong wind brought it crashing down, nest, Eagles, and all. Some of them were killed by the fall; others were eaten by birds and beasts of prey, and the Rabbit finally had the satisfaction of destroying the Eagle's children in revenge for her own.

abstemius_75.original: Story: There was once a Ram who defeated all his fellow rams and became so proud of his victories that he decided to challenge a Bull to a fight. They met, and at the first clash, the Ram was knocked out and lay as if dead. When he came to, he said, 'This is the result of my arrogance and foolishness in challenging an enemy that nature made stronger than me.'

abstemius_79.response: It is foolish to complain about the inevitable, lest you suffer an even greater fate.
abstemius_79.original: Story: A Sheep that was about to be sheared was upset with the Shepherd for not being content with the Milk she provided, but also taking her Wool. The Shepherd, without further words, angrily took one of the Lambs and killed it. 'Well,' said the Sheep, 'I hope you've done your worst now.' 'No,' said the Shepherd, 'when that's done, I can cut your throat too if I want, and throw you to the Dogs or Wolves as I please.' The Sheep said nothing more, fearing something worse might happen.

abstemius_87_extra.response: No one should have all the advantages.
abstemius_87_extra.original: Story: The rabbit and the fox made their petitions to Jupiter: the fox asked that swiftness of foot be added to her slyness, and the rabbit asked that slyness be added to his swiftness. Jupiter responded to them as follows: 'From the beginning of the world, from my breast I have poured forth gifts to each and every animal very generously; if I were to give one animal all the fits, that would be an injury to the others.'

abstemius_80.response: It is not the strong who make the most noise, but the weak.
abstemius_80.original: Story: A Waggoner noticed that the noisiest wheel was the worst of the four and wondered why. 'Ah,' said the Wagon, 'those who are weak are always the loudest and most troublesome.'

abstemius_81.response: A true friend is known in times of adversity.
abstemius_81.original: Story: There was a generous Rich Man who always had a grand and open table, so he never lacked guests. This man noticed that all sorts of people came to him, and he became curious to see who were true friends and who were just freeloaders. So one day, at a full table, he mentioned a quarrel he had and said he was about to seek satisfaction. He needed a certain number of people to join him, and he was sure they would stand by him with swords in hand. Everyone made excuses except for two, whom he counted as his friends, while the rest were just hangers-on.

When the dog was crossing the river, he saw the reflection of the meat in the water, and it seemed much larger than the meat he was carrying. He dropped his own piece of meat in order to try to snatch at the reflection. When the reflection disappeared, the dog went to grab the meat he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing raven had immediately snatched the meat and gobbled it up. The dog lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.'",
Expected response: Do not grasp at more than you need.

Story: There was a generous Rich Man who always had a grand and open table, so he never lacked guests. This man noticed that all sorts of people came to him, and he became curious to see who were true friends and who were just freeloaders. So one day, at a full table, he mentioned a quarrel he had and said he was about to seek satisfaction. He needed a certain number of people to join him, and he was sure they would stand by him with swords in hand. Everyone made excuses except for two, whom he counted as his friends, while the rest were just hangers-on.

abstemius_72.response: Appearances can be deceiving, and true character will ultimately be revealed.
abstemius_72.original: Story: There is a story of a Wolf that wrapped himself in a sheep's skin and attacked lambs for a while under that disguise. But the shepherd eventually caught him and hung him up, sheep's skin and all, on a high gallows as a warning and example. The neighbors were amazed and asked why he hung up his sheep. 'Oh,' he said, 'that's just the skin of a sheep that was used to cover the heart, malice, and body of a wolf that hid under it.'

abstemius_83.response: It is not outward appearance that determines one's true worth or abilities.
abstemius_83.original: Story: Quite a few horses had been brought to the race track, all adorned with elaborate accoutrements, all except for one, so the other horses made fun of him for being so shabby and unsuited to this type of competition, and they concluded that he would not ever be a winner. But when the time for the running of the race arrived and the trumpet blew the signal to start, all the horses leaped from their starting cages, and only then did it become clear how much the horse who had just been made fun of actually outdistanced the rest of the horses with his speed. When all the others had been left far behind, that horse won the palm of victory.

abstemius_84.response: Gifts can open doors that would otherwise remain closed to those in need.
abstemius_84.original: Story: A Countryman who was caught up in a lawsuit had a close friend and relative who was a lawyer. He went to him again and again for advice, but the lawyer was always too busy and told him to come back another time. The poor man took a nice, fat kid goat with him on his next visit, and when the lawyer's clerk heard the goat at the door, he let the man in and took him to his master. There, the man explained his case, got the lawyer's opinion, thanked the lawyer for seeing him, and thanked the goat for getting him in, and then went on his way.

abstemius_85.response: Excessive indulgence in pleasure can lead to exhaustion and weakness.
abstemius_85.original: Story: A certain young man had married a woman who was also quite young, very beautiful and lusty. Wanting to satisfy her boundless appetite, his loins had gotten so worn out that after just a few days he had gotten thin and looked more dead than alive: he could not walk, he could not stand up, he could do any kind of work, and so like some kind of old man he took his pleasure in the sun. So when he was enjoying some sunny place, warming himself by the sun's heat, it happened that some hunters, who had been chasing a wolf, came that way. When the young man asked them why they hadn't caught the wolf, they replied, 'We were not able to pursue him because of his incredible swiftness.' 'Well,' he said, 'if my wife were in charge of him, she'd put an end to his running.'

abstemius_82.response: It is foolish to expect gratitude for praising someone to their advantage.
abstemius_82.original: Story: As a Dog was chasing closely behind a Fox, a Hare suddenly appeared. 'Hold on a moment,' said the Fox, 'and catch that Hare while you can. You've never tasted such a treat in your life. But I'm all spoiled and rotten, and a bite of my flesh would poison you.' The Dog immediately left the Fox and chased after the Hare, but she was too quick for him. When he realized he couldn't catch her, he wisely let her go. The Hare had overheard what happened, and when she met the Fox a few days later, she told him how badly he had treated her. 'Well,' said the Fox, 'if you are upset that I spoke well of you, what would you have done if I had spoken badly?'

abstemius_87.response: It is foolish to expect that something you possess will be sacrificed for the promise of something potentially greater.
abstemius_87.original: Story: As a Nightingale was singing in a bush, down swoops a sneaky Sparrow-Hawk and snatches her from the branch. The poor Nightingale pleaded for her life, saying that her small body wasn't worth it and that there were bigger birds to catch. The Hawk replied, 'Do you think I'm so foolish as to give up a little bird I have for a bigger one I don't have?' Then she offered, 'I'll sing you a lovely song for my life.' 'No, no,' said the Hawk, 'I need food for my belly, not music for my ears.'

abstemius_88.response: Loyalty and faithfulness are the qualities that true friendship values.
abstemius_88.original: Story: A Lion, who found it very bothersome to live alone, let the Beasts of the Forest know that he had decided to choose one of them as a Friend and Companion. There was a great commotion about who would be the Favorite and the envy of all the others. The Lion chose a Hog, saying, 'He is true and faithful to his friend and will stand by him in all times and dangers.'

abstemius_90.response: Everyone has a role to play, no matter their abilities.
abstemius_90.original: Story: When a war broke out between the Birds and the Beasts, the Lion called all his subjects from ages sixteen to sixty to gather with weapons at a specific time and place, or face his great displeasure. Among those who showed up were many Asses and Hares. Some of the leaders wanted to dismiss them, thinking they were not fit for service. 'Do not be mistaken,' said the Lion, 'the Asses will do well as trumpeters, and the Hares will make excellent letter-carriers.'

Story: When a war broke out between the Birds and the Beasts, the Lion called all his subjects from ages sixteen to sixty to gather with weapons at a specific time and place, or face his great displeasure. Among those who showed up were many Asses and Hares. Some of the leaders wanted to dismiss them, thinking they were not fit for service. 'Do not be mistaken,' said the Lion, 'the Asses will do well as trumpeters, and the Hares will make excellent letter-carriers.'

abstemius_extra_53.original: Story: An elm tree sprang up on the bank of a river, and the elm tree mocked the willow tree who was her neighbor for being weak and feeble, as it bent with every surge of the water, no matter how light, while the elm tree praised her own stoutness and strength with extravagant words, because for many years the elm tree had remained unshaken by even the most persistent movement of the stream. On one occasion, however, the elm tree snapped from the tremendous violence of the waves and as she was being dragged along by the waters the willow tree laughed and said: Why are you abandoning me, neighbor? Where is your stoutness now?'

abstemius_86.response: Kind words and gentle means should be tried first, but firmness and severity may sometimes be necessary.
abstemius_86.original: Story: An Old Man caught a Boy stealing apples from his orchard. 'Hey,' he said, 'come down from that tree and stop taking my apples.' The Boy ignored him and kept picking. 'Well,' said the Old Man, 'they say herbs have magic just like words do,' and he threw a handful of grass at the Boy. This was so silly that the Young Thief thought the Old Man was joking. But finally, the Old Man said, 'If words and herbs won't work, I'll try stones, because they say stones have power too,' and with that, he got the job done.

abstemius_95.response: Wealth acquired through wicked means will bring joy to none but those who will misuse it.
abstemius_95.original: Story: There was a certain miserly man who was dying and about to part with his enormous heap of money, ill-gotten as it was. He ordered that the bag of coins be brought to him as he was dying and then asked the bag to whom it would bring pleasure. The bag answered him: 'I'm going to bring pleasure to your heirs, who will squander these coins, over which you sweated, on women and drinks, and I'll also bring pleasure to the demons who are going to turn your soul over to eternal torments.'

abstemius_91.response: Beware of helping those who may turn against you once their internal conflicts are resolved.
abstemius_91.original: Story: Once there was a fierce civil war among the Hawks. The gentle and innocent Pigeons, out of pure kindness, sent their representatives to try and make peace between them. While the Hawks were busy fighting each other, they paid no attention to anything else. But as soon as they made peace, they returned to their old habit of attacking the Pigeons. This made the Pigeons realize their mistake and understand the danger of helping a common enemy, which led to their own downfall.

abstemius_89.response: Hard work is more valuable than idle amusement.
abstemius_89.original: Story: A Gnat, nearly frozen and hungry, went to a Bee-Hive on a cold morning to ask for help. The Gnat offered to teach music to the Bee's family in exchange for food and shelter. The Bee politely declined, saying, 'I teach all my children my own trade so they can earn a living through hard work.'

abstemius_94.response: One should always be prepared for the inevitable, for death is a part of life and can come at any moment.
abstemius_94.original: Story: There is a story that Death visited an Old Man and told him to come along. The Man tried to excuse himself, saying that the journey to the Other World was too long to take on such short notice, and he asked for a little more time to make his Will before he died. Death replied, 'You have had enough warning, one would think, to have been ready by now.' 'In truth,' said the Old Man, 'this is the first time I have ever seen you in my whole life.' 'That's not true,' said Death, 'for you have seen daily examples of mortality before your eyes, in people of all kinds, ages, and ranks. Isn't the frequent sight of others' deaths a reminder enough to make you think of your own? Your dim and hollow eyes, the loss of your hearing, and the faltering of your other senses should remind you, without much ado, that Death has already taken hold of you. And do you think this is the time to keep putting it off? Your final hour, I tell you, has now come, and there's no thought of a reprieve in the case of Fate.'
